commitResults.messageTitle: Update Duke.java to handle new Tasks Types
Add exception handling of user inputs

commitResults.messageBody:
Currently the Arraylist of Tasks in Duke.java is lost after the program exits.

This makes the program vulnerable to power loss and accidental exits.

Therefore this commit updates Duke.java to save the Arraylist data to "data/data.bin" and load from it if the file exists on start.
It also updates Task.java to make the class implement Serailizable for this purpose.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update Deadline.java to store dates as LocalDate
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently deadline task stores dates as a String type.

This allows for undesirable inputs as format is not enforced.

This commit changes this String field to a LocalDate type, allowing for more functionality in the future

commitResults.messageTitle: Add Command class and its subclasses
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently all the functionality of the program is handled internally in
Duke.java

This  increases the difficultly in adding and editing commands while
maintaining code correctness.

Therefore, this commit will add a new Command class as well as sub
classes for the various commands to make the project more
Object oriented.

This is a new class that handles parsing String input from users and
returns the appropriate Command object.

This class contains the functions to handle the storage and retrieval of
the task list.
Class that defines and prints messages to the screen.

Duke class handles all the logic in the program from parsing, storage,
printing, and managing an internal list of Tasks.

Adding new features will prove challenging as the project grows.

Let's separate the functionality of Duke into individual classes
following a more OOP design.

commitResults.messageTitle: Move classes into suitable java packages
Tweak code to comply with coding standard

commitResults.messageBody:
Task list can get arbitrarily long as users add more tasks.

This makes locating the index of a desired task challenging.

Let's,
* add a new command class called FindCommand that allows users
to search for tasks that is in the task list.
* update Ui.java to support new messages generated by this command.
* update Parser.java to parse user input "find" to the new command.
